channel.title: Isosurface Tests (Open-source)
channel.description:
In an effort to better improve my game Codename::World, I've been researching new methods of extracting isosurfaces from data sets. I'm making my findings open-source. Some of the code is borrowed/inspired by existing implementations, but most is my own. It's not very optimized and it doesn't have much of a use outside of displaying data. It requires XNA 4.0 to build and run.
[url=https://github.com/Lin20/isosurface][b][size=16pt]GitHub Repository[/size][/b][/url]
You can find a download under "Releases". Make sure to install the XNA 4.0 Redistributable: http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=20914
[b][u]Currently Mostly Implemented Algorithms[/u][/b]
[ul][li]2D Uniform Dual Contouring[/li] [li]2D Adaptive Dual Contouring[/li] [li]3D Uniform Dual Contouring[/li] [li]3D Adaptive Dual Contouring[/li][/ul]
[b][u]Bugs/Errors/Notes[/u][/b]
[ul][li]The 2D implementations don't connect properly; they were my first tests with DC and have some issues, and the adaptive implementation doesn't have simplification[/li] [li]My QEF solver is hardly a QEF solver; Rather, it takes a set of offsets to apply to the mass point and find the one that has the lowest error, so do [b]not[/b] use this as an example[/li] [li]The QEF solver is disabled in the 3D implementations but can be enabled (simplification needs some tweaks); sharp features will be lost and mesh will be deformed if the error tolerance is high without it[/li][/ul]
[b][u]Controls[/u][/b] Space - Adjust quality (ADC3D only) Tab - Switch algorithm 1 - Toggle mesh visibility 2 - Toggle outline/tree visiblity 3 - Toggle solid/wireframe/both rasterization C - Toggle mouse locking
[b][u]Screenshots[/u][/b] [img width=480 height=480]http://i.imgur.com/7LLNFut.png[/img] [img width=480 height=276]http://i.imgur.com/LXRlpMT.png[/img] [img width=480 height=480]http://i.imgur.com/IrZbR8t.png[/img] [img width=480 height=480]http://i.imgur.com/js5tP9Q.png[/img] [img width=480 height=480]http://i.imgur.com/xO0sOmG.png[/img] [img width=480 height=480]http://i.imgur.com/5lErOA1.png[/img]

@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:9, topic:553353”][quote author=sini link=topic=672269.msg4501745#msg4501745 date=1451792126]

[quote author=Pwnd link=topic=672269.msg4501739#msg4501739 date=1451773589]

You use to call me on my Skype phone, late at night when you needed my loovvveeee
[/quote]pls die

This doesn’t concern you.
[/quote]At least make “love” as “code”…[/quote]

Well more or less I loved seeing his code :[ But seriously Lin liking what Im seeing. If you get some time you should try and explain it to my fat ass on Skyoope.

Read full topic

item.title: Isosurface Tests (Open-source)
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

For anyone who was following the progress of this, I finished my research and implemented Manifold Dual Contouring. It’s the only public implementation of it and you can check out the source code in the same repo.

Paper: http://faculty.cs.tamu.edu/schaefer/research/dualsimp_tvcg.pdf

Various Screenshots:

XBHQp9X.jpg2328×1748

oZoWm5o.jpg1726×2200

lcVkVc3.png1300×575

6BlZwDJ.jpg1993×2500

Read full topic

item.title: Isosurface Tests (Open-source)
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

In an effort to better improve my game Codename::World, I’ve been researching new methods of extracting isosurfaces from data sets. I’m making my findings open-source. Some of the code is borrowed/inspired by existing implementations, but most is my own. It’s not very optimized and it doesn’t have much of a use outside of displaying data. It requires XNA 4.0 to build and run.

[size=16pt]GitHub Repository[/size]

You can find a download under “Releases”. Make sure to install the XNA 4.0 Redistributable: http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=20914

Currently Mostly Implemented Algorithms

[ul][li]2D Uniform Dual Contouring[/li]
[li]2D Adaptive Dual Contouring[/li]
[li]3D Uniform Dual Contouring[/li]
[li]3D Adaptive Dual Contouring[/li][/ul]

Bugs/Errors/Notes

[ul][li]The 2D implementations don’t connect properly; they were my first tests with DC and have some issues, and the adaptive implementation doesn’t have simplification[/li]
[li]My QEF solver is hardly a QEF solver; Rather, it takes a set of offsets to apply to the mass point and find the one that has the lowest error, so do not use this as an example[/li]
[li]The QEF solver is disabled in the 3D implementations but can be enabled (simplification needs some tweaks); sharp features will be lost and mesh will be deformed if the error tolerance is high without it[/li][/ul]

Controls
Space - Adjust quality (ADC3D only)
Tab - Switch algorithm
1 - Toggle mesh visibility
2 - Toggle outline/tree visiblity
3 - Toggle solid/wireframe/both rasterization
C - Toggle mouse locking

Screenshots

LXRlpMT.png1606×925
